Questions.QuestionText: This tall lawyer from Illinois guided the nation through its Civil War and issued the Emancipation Proclamation.
He led the Continental Army to victory, chopped down the cherry tree… or so the legend says.
Elected four times, he led the U.S. through the Great Depression and most of World War II with his New Deal policies.
He penned the Declaration of Independence and loved a good Monticello sunset.
This youngest elected president faced the Cuban Missile Crisis and famously challenged Americans to “ask not what your country can do for you.”
Before leading the U.S., he commanded Allied forces in Europe during World War II and warned of the “military-industrial complex.
He signed the Civil Rights Act into law and escalated U.S. involvement in the Vietnam War.
He defended British soldiers after the Boston Massacre, helped draft the Declaration of Independence, and became the second U.S. president.
This former peanut farmer from Georgia brokered the Camp David Accords and later won a Nobel Peace Prize.
He led the U.S. during the Spanish-American War and was assassinated early into his second term.
